Checklist
 
A) I know it's an obvious one but you can adjust the call volume.
 
B) Is the mesh covering the earpiece at the top of the phone completely clean and dust free? 
 
C) Does this happen during all calls from several call received  or restricted to a one caller only? Could be problem the other parties phone. 
 
D) Try adapting the sound to suit you,  you can do this by going into settings, sound and vibration, sound quality and effects then adapt sound. It will also ask what ear you use to call receive or take calls normally. 
 
E) Try putting into safe mode just to rule out an app is causing the issue. 
 
F) is your hearing Ok? 
 
If still issue then I would get it checked out as most likely to be a fault.

HDR isnt a "real" thing. It's a marketing technique.  
What it technically is is 10bit color as opposed to 8bit color. This reduces banding. Then there's a software layer preventing non HDR-branded screens from playing beck the same video.
 
Note that while it was supposed to be part of the HDR "standard" to acctually have a 10bit display, good contrast and good brightness, those are completely OPTIONAL for a screen to be "HDR". Meaning a low end HDR branded screen will be much worse than a old high end screen that doesnt support HDR.

In August we heard that Samsung bought up almost all available Snapdragon 845 chips from Qualcomm for its Galaxy S9 and S9+ duo. Today a new report basically confirms that the entire first production run of the new chipset will be sold to Samsung for its S9 phones. 
The S9 and S9+ with the Snapdragon 845 inside are destined for the US market, unsurprisingly. Other smartphone makers will get access to the 845 at a later point compared to Samsung, which will thus once again have a time-to-market advantage over its competitors from this point of view.
 
Basically the same thing that's described here has happened this year with the S8 duo and the Snapdragon 835. Samsung buying up all available units of that chip forced LG to use the older Snapdragon 821 in its G6, while other companies simply postponed their flagship launches by a few months in order to ensure a decent supply of 835s. 
The same source also claims that the S9 duo will be launching a month earlier than usual, which means we can expect them to be in stores in mid-March. If this is true, then an announcement at MWC in late February seems likely. Obviously do take all of the above with a pinch of salt, it's just another rumor at the moment - though it does confirm earlier mumblings, for what it's worth.

Clearly you people don't know how RAM is managed by Android... the readout of 1.6GB that you're seeing is the amount of RAM free at that moment... Android uses as much RAM as it requires to give you a snappy experience[I.e caching] so the amount of used RAM that your device is telling you is being used is not permanently occupied by the OS... When you open multiple applications that need more than the indicated free RAM available, your device frees up that space for your applications to utilise... So don't get worried by the fact that you have very little free RAM available because that readout is meaningless.... Unused RAM is wasted RAM in Android... 4GB is more than plenty

An Android with 2GB of RAM is like an iPhone with only 512MB of RAM. You can't compare Android and iOS based on their hardware specs. Android and iOS are different operating systems. Android uses more resources, thus it needs more RAM. iPhone on the other hand uses less resources, thus it needs less RAM compared to Android. My Samsung Galaxy S5 has 2GB of RAM, and it cannot hold as many apps open in RAM as an iPhone with 2GB of RAM would, even on near-to-stock Android. With 4GB of RAM, I think my S5 would be able to hold a lot more apps open, nearly as much as an iPhone. That's just how it works. Even if Android tried to better its RAM management, I don't think it'd be enough because it's just more resource heavy than iOS.

OP3T is a great phone, no doubt on that. But here are the things that differs it with S8: 
1. 3T is a bit larger. The 3T has bigger footprint even though it has smaller screen size (5.5" vs 5.8"). For some people it doesn't matter (I know I don't mind a few mm shorter screen). But where S8 shines is that it has slimmer screen, which is a joy to hold. I've used phones like SGN4, which was a phablet and one of the thickest phones around. Using S8 feels great in the hand day to day basis. S8 fans, don't talk about the PPI, please. It really doesn't matter in real life. 90% of the people never even will use the full WQHD+ resolution in S8 than the FHD+. 
2. S8 has IP68 rating whereas 3T has none. Maybe it is not important for many, but as I ride my bike regularly, I have the fear of rain pouring on my phone. The water resistance protects my device from going brick. 
3. 3T has bigger base memory (64GB/128GB), whereas S8 has only 64GB. But it can be topped up with upto 256GB (theoretically 2TB, but it's not available yet) MicroSD Card. I have put a 200GB inside and still am quite happy with the performance. It didn't slow down, doesn't restart. Those who doesn't need extra memory, 3T is a better option for them. 
4. Both the front camera and the rear camera is better than S8, theoretically, that is. Just the Mega Pixel isn't everything. Mega Pixel is the sensor size, how much pixels the sensor has to capture the picture. But the lens and picture processing is also important to get a great picture. The pictures of 3T is very much post-able in social media, where most of the people sees it in a phone's screen anyway. But comparing S8's & 3T's pictures side by side will show you the difference. S8 competes (DXOMarks Score 88) with PixelXL (DXOMarks Score 89) & HTC U11 (DXOMarks Score 90), whereas, 3T is nowhere to be seen in the list down to Score 80. Then again, who uses mobile pictures in a bigger screen now-a-days anyway? For actual photographers there are DSLRs. 
5. The BT 5.0 is nothing to frown for if you don't have it. Yes, having it on board is fun. For example, I let my kid play game in the phone while the game sound comes through the device's speaker and I listen to the music through a BT speaker in the other room simultaneously. but living without it is very much possible. 
6. The USB port could have been 3.1 or 3.2 in 3T, then it would have been faster in data transfer than the available 2.0 in 3T. 
7. Even after the battery being larger than S8, 3T can deliver the same to S8, not higher (refer to the battery test of GSMA and other reviewers). And 3) How important is camera and imaging to you?

As the older option, the iPhone is likely going to have some cheap contract options now. But iPhones tend to retain their value for 2 generations. So, if you should choose to upgrade in the next 2 years, the iPhone would be a more cost effective option, likely drawing a bigger resale.

So, it's been a week with my new Samsung Galaxy S8 & as promised, here is my pure user review. 
The screen of the S8 is amazing, I mean, simply amazing. I keep on staring at it all day long. Luckily my phone doesn't have any red tint issue or restart issue. I'm loving every moment with it. It's fluent and fast. Those who are complaining about Samsung's laggy TouchWiz should use this phone for a while. It's totally new and swift, doesn't lag anymore, but stammers sometimes (there is a difference between lagging and stammering). Will it lag in the future? Well, that's only time can tell. For now, it's better than previous generations. 
I've got a theory on this. My last Samsung product was a Note 4 from 2014. At that time Android couldn't do multitasking in split screen, couldn't do floating apps, couldn't do a lot of things that my Note 4 could do. To enable them Samsung had to go through a lot of skinning. But now Android itself can do all those things, so Samsung could make S8 lighter than before. That's why the UI is so light this time around. 
Yes, when you press the Bixby button, it waits for a while (why, I don't know). Other than that, all my commands are executed perfectly. I downloaded some benchmark apps and my device's score is mostly higher than that of the review devices in the published review units around the word. 
Btw, I don't know why they have put the Bixby button there without finalizing it properly. Though I've never "accidentally" pressed it, sometimes it annoys me that there is a button and I can't use it properly. Yeah, I know thay I can remap it with apps, but I was talking about using Bixby, not something else. 
The battery is not as good as I expected. It's not giving me a whole day service. Then again, I come from Note 4 and nothing can compete Samsung's Note series there. But it may also because I keep watching YouTube, browse net, play games like Temple Run 2, Flight Pilot or Robbery Bob 2, listening to music, and obviously, taking notes and doing office works in it. But the fast charge and the wireless charger on my office desk covers me there. So I think I'm good for the time being. 
I am used to with a 12.2" screen with four part split screen (Note Pro did spoil me there), so I don't find the split screen unusable. And on top of that, the floating apps does come in handy in times. The edge screen is very useful and only those who never ever used it will call it a gimmick. The keyboard is good, very easy to type or swipe. I'm using it now to write the user review, btw. 
The download speed is great, so is the upload speed. I find my S8 grabbing all the Wi-Fi data in my home and other devices those are connected in my home have to put on a fighr to get a chance for the net. 
What I hate about the phone is that it's a fingerprint magnet. I can't keep it open to show off the back. I had to put it in a case to protect it from fingerprints and scratches (did I forget to tell you that S8 is much more fragile than other phones out there? But as I'm a grown up and matured person, I don't drop my phone. I take a good care of it. It's your own carefulness that will keep your phone broken or intact.) 
The cameras are pretty good. They are on par with iP7+, LGG6, GPixel etc. The front camera is great. But I find the faces turned out softened. No matter how much "beauty face" I turn down, it still "smoothen" my face. The 3D view is one thing I'm crazy about, though I'm unable to publish it like a 360 cam in social sites. Oh, I love to take videos of the fishes in the aquarium (and my friends are jealous of that). 
As I told earlier, I don't have any problem with the fingerprint scanner on the back. Yeah, it's placed oddly, but I checked it before buying and I don't hate it (neither am I a fan of the placement) I don't use face unlock. Instead, I use iris scanner. The more I use it, the snappier it becomes. It opens everything in a mere fraction of a second. And it works perfectly in the dark too. Only in the morning it asks me to open my eyes more, LOL. 
I don't use Bixby, neither did I stop it from working. I just talk with Google Assistant instead, that's it. 
The sound quality is loud & good enough through the speaker and the headphone. Both are clear, to the least.

Go to the specification of Galaxy S8 in GSMArena.com, then click the compare button. After the page loads, in the "compare" section, type Galaxy S8+ and hit "Enter". Then let the page reload. But if you ask me, the following are the plus points for S8 & S8+ over S7e: 
1. Bigger screen (6.2"(S8+) VS 5.5" OR 5.8"(S8) VS 5.5") - S8+ is much bigger, while S8 is about the same size as S7e 
2. Newer Chipset (Snapdragon 835 VS Snapdragon 820 OR Exynos 8895 VS Exynos 8890 - 10nm VS 14 nm) - S8 & S8+ are better 
3. Screen comes with better "palm rejection" than S7e 
4. Lighter touchwiz (now called Samsung Experience) 
5. Better onboard storage (64GB VS 32 GB) 
6. Has Iris Scanner now (S7e don't) 
7. Fingerprint Scanner is in an awkward position. But it is tough to reach it on S8+, easy on the S8, even for smaller hands (Those who complain about the Fingerprint scanner unreachability on S8 may have puny hands) 
And the followings are the plus points of S7e over the other two: 
1. Being the last years flagship it is much cheaper than it was (actually half of it's initial release) 
2. The camera on S7e is not far behind of S8 & S8+ 
3. The battery of S7e is better than S8 & S8+ (3600mAh VS 3000mAh & 3500mAh) 
4. Still a good looking phone 
5. Has the same IP68 rating and the option to top the storage upto 256GB (that is the highest available until now) 
So the decision is yours now. But one thing I must add, being the newer, S8 & S8+ will have more upgrades than S7e. But that is not an issue if you do a custom ROM. You still dont understand bezel less concept. The idea is to use the bezel and turn it into screen. They never really want to increase screen size. Samsung just want to maximize usable area on the phone itself. Lets say you have galaxy s7 edge. You see the top and bottom bezel. Turn those bezel to usable screen without changing the form factor. You practically turn or stretch a 16:9 screen into 18.5:9 just like you see here on s8; without changing the width. That is the point of bezel less. Its pretty much adding screen to the top and bottom bezel. You still have that 16:9 screen, plus additional screen real estate where it used to be your capacitive keys(bottom) and samsung logo(top) on s7 edge. The 12MP camera from last year's SGS7, SGS7e & SGN7 were one of the best (if not the best) mobile phone cameras around. After the last year's problem with SGN7, the company faced huge loss. People were looking forward for the Note 7, but had to choose a different device instead. And in the phone market, it's not unlikely to move away from one company to another. So Samsung faced a huge loss there. 
This year, the release of SGS8 & SGS8+ was huge for Samsung. If they make any mistake, they will be gone from the number one position. So they are playing very careful. If you have followed the tech world for the last three months, you will know that Samsung has promoted on how they are checking the battery on eight levels to avoid any mishaps. This is to build trust among the users. That is why Samsung wanted to create a full screen phone, a phone that was supposed to be marketed a few years later. But to make that happen they needed to make sure that the camera is not worse than last year. We all know that SGS7 & SGS7e had one of the best cameras of last year. So they changed the module, but kept the resolution same (so that the algorithm behind the sensor can be the same, at least) and worked on the software (but not much). They just made sure that the low-light performance is at least a bit better from last year, which they did ensure (somewhat). That's why SGS7 & SGS8 has the camera of the same resolution, but NOT the same units. 
On a side note, Samsung wanted to make the All-Screen phone later, not this year. But to pull the consumers toward them, they had to move forth with the idea sooner than they expected. That is why Synaptics didn't get the chance to finish the work on the Screen Fingerprint Scanner and Samsung had to put the Fingerprint Scanner somewhere. The front of the phone had no place and the back of the phone has battery on the middle. My best guess is that SGS8 was supposed to have a dual sensor camera and they had the place freed up for the Fingerprint Scanner (don't judge me for the guess, it might be wrong). But whatever the problem was, the scanner ended up in an awkward place, no doubt. 
And if the rumors are true, the SGN8 will have the Iris scanner, as well as the Fingerprint Scanner embedded under the screen, as well as the dual camera. Well, that's the future to tell, right? Ciao...

An update on GS8 & GS8+. 
I got to see and hold the S8 & S8+ on 14th April, OMG, they are gorgeous. I got a chance to use them for a while (as much as I could in the display units) and I would say they are better in person. It seems that Samsung has worked on the palm rejection and now it didn't bother me as much as on SG7e. I got a chance to hold the LGG6 as well. That's another good device, I'll have to say. But looks wise, SGS8 is the best looking device at present, in my opinion. I have rather small hands and I could hold the S8 without any problem. Even better, it felt very good in my hand and I could reach the awkward placed Fingerprint scanner with ease. But it wasn't the case with SGS8+. It felt large and I was unable to reach the back without some palm acrobats. 
Now, there will be no Bixby, at least, not in the beginning. The plan Samsung have with it is large. So, it will be huge when it comes in full, but till then I'd rather use Google Assistant. The UI seemed lighter this time around, so there's a slim chance that the device will not slow down in a year. But, who knows, right? 
The price of the pre-ordered units are around 950 USD here in Bangladesh. I know, I know, they are very expensive. But they will provide 160 USD worth of Samsung DEx (fast charging) with it, so it will become 790 USD. And the shop that I pre-ordered with, Gadget&Gear, they will provide a 128GB Micro-SD card, worth 85 USD, which will reduce the price to almost 705 USD, which, in my sense, is a pretty good deal. 
I wanted an Orchid Grey version of the S8 with Exynos chipset, as many of you might know by now, but unfortunately we will be getting the obvious Midnight Black, Coral Blue (for SGS8+ only) and Maple Gold here in Bangladesh. So I settled for the common Midnight Black instead. Samsung promised to ship the devices on 8th May, 2017, all fingers crossed. 
As far about the battery, some YouTubers recently showed that the battery of SGS8+ is marginally better than that of SGS8. So I think we're good here. As long as it supports me around 18 hours (from 6am to 12am), I think I'll love it.

I seldom comment here on the User Opinions, because I don't like to confront with people. Regarding the SGS8, one must understand the following things while comparing it with SGS7e: 
1. The new processor is an upgrade from the last flagship (SGS7e or SGS7), which is now more powerful (a little, if not highly powerful) and faster (yet again, a little) 
2. The battery of SGS8 is 3000mAh, may not seem much on the paper, but reviewers all around the world in the web and in YouTube have confirmed that the battery is enough to work your way throughout the day using your phone moderately. For heavy users, it will last till dinner time. The reason for this is the SGN7 and now Samsung wants to play safe. If this year anything happens to SGS8 or SGS8+, then they will be in deep trouble. The battery is good, but not one among the best. That is why Sammy didn't even say anything about the battery life of the new flagships. 
3. RAM is good in my book. If a phone's OS knows how to "manage" RAM, then it doesn't need more RAM like 6GB or so. For example, look at iPhone's 3GB RAM. It's "NOT ADEQUATE" in someone's book, but is quite good in service. It's all about RAM management. Yet, Sammy is offering a 6GB version of the SGS8+, those who are complaining about the 4GB RAM being too low, can buy them instead. But as I know, those companies who are boasting about 6GB RAM in their phones can't provide a code for better RAM management. 
4. ROM is another thing everyone is complaining about. Well, in this case, the bigger is the better. A certain portion of the ROM memory will be occupied by the phone as usual, the user gets the rest. When a phone upgrades, the main OS embedded never gets erased, but the link is just re-positioned from the previous OS. So it is possible to downgrade your phone after the upgrade using "flash", until and unless you delete/erase it deliberately. 
5. People are saying that the camera is the same as SGS7/SGS7e. Well, in paper it is SIMILAR, not the same. They have used similar lens with same focus ability, but better sensor underneath. But bear it in mind, that the camera upgrade is NOT much from last year's flagships. Now the camera of SGS8/SGS8+ can take better low-light picture because it takes more than one photos in a mere second and combine them to reduce noise in the final display. The front facing camera though, got an upgrade. The 8MP camera looks good in paper. But the main feature that I like over the previous phones is that it now has auto focus and facial recognition, a much wanted feature. 
6. The screen looks gorgeous, absolutely stunning, to be honest. BUT, I personally am NOT a fan of 18:9 ratio. Though it is what made the screen look better, I liked 16:9 ratio better. None-the-less, this is one of the best screen available for cell-phones available today. 
7. The security is very strong on SGS8/SGS8+. You have fingerprint scanner (don't let me start on this). Sammy wanted to put an under-the-screen scanner, which was unavailable before the product launch. So they crammed the fingerprint scanner wherever they could - at the back, in a very awkward place. This is very hard to reach for both hands and a tall phone should have this even lower. But I'm glad that there is Iris-scanner present. Like the SGN7, the Iris-scanner is fast and accurate. But I wouldn't depend so much on the facial recognition, as it can be fooled by a picture of yours. 
8. I don't want to talk about the Bixby. Let it roll first, if I use it, I'll know how much it worth. But for now, I prefer Google assistant over it. 
9. Funny enough, now a days people don't argue much on the main thing that a phone is supposed to do, make and receive a call. Don't you think that should be our main concern on a phone? As far as my concern, the phones have great reception. The clarity is great over the network. 
Last, but not least, would you buy a SGS8/SGS8+ if you already have SGS7/SGS7e? Yes and no. If you have SGS7, then you should try out the edge screen and it's features. It's different. If you have SGS7e, then you might give it a thought. Is the Iris-scanner attracting you too much? Does the 18.5:9 ratio feels worth to you? There's nothing much on SGS8/SGS8+ other than the bigger screen, Iris-scanner, bezel-less display. The awkward fingerprint scanner is a no-go to me. 
If you don't have the last year's flagship (any make), do you need to upgrade? Definitely yes, if you have the cash. A lot has changed in the last two years. So if you have the cash in your wallet, go out and check the recent flagship and buy one of this year. 
If you're an iPhone user, do you need to upgrade to SGS8/SGS8+? Definitely no. You are into Apple environment because you like it. iPhone users should wait for the iPhone8 or iPhoneX, whichever they name it. As far as the rumor going, this is supposed to be awesome. 
So, this is what I wanted to say. Sorry for the long post. Hit thumbs up if you like what I said. I would love to get constructive criticism. Ciao...
